decision.reasoning:
My analysis points to the market being overconfident in the Seattle Seahawks. The current price of 66.3% for a Seahawks victory is higher than the probability assigned by at least one major analytical model, ESPN Analytics, which places their chances at 60.2%. This discrepancy suggests the crowd may be pushing the price up beyond the fundamental odds.

As a contrarian, I'm drawn to situations where public sentiment is overwhelmingly one-sided. The search results repeatedly mention "one-way traffic on Seattle," which is a classic indicator of heavy public betting on the favorite. Sportsbooks often find themselves needing the underdog to win in these scenarios. While some sharp money may have initially moved the line to favor Seattle, the overall narrative suggests a public pile-on, which is an environment ripe for a contrarian bet.

Furthermore, the Patriots are not being dismissed as a no-hope underdog. The spread is a manageable 4.5 points, implying a competitive game rather than a blowout. There are also specific counter-arguments to the Seahawks' dominance, such as their defense giving up 12 explosive plays in the NFC Championship and the Patriots' defense being "quietly just as good."

Given the inflated market price relative to analytical models and the strong public sentiment favoring Seattle, I see value in taking the opposite position. The implied probability of a Patriots win is only 33.7% (100% - 66.3%), which I believe is too low. I am betting that the crowd is wrong and that the Patriots' chances are better than the market currently reflects.

The bull case for the Patriots is built on a powerful and specific mismatch: their elite, #1-ranked passing offense (by EPA/Dropback) against a Seattle defense that, while ranked #1 overall, can be vulnerable. Furthermore, the narrative favoring Seattle relies heavily on quarterback Sam Darnold repeating one of the best games

search_results.query: Super Bowl LX pregame warmup Drake Maye Geno Smith status

results.title: Super Bowl 60: Where to watch, kickoff time and everything you need to know
results.snippet: There will also be hours' worth of pregame coverage starting at 1 p.m.

results.title: Patriots hold first official practice of Super Bowl week, Drake Maye "feeling great" - CBS Boston
results.snippet: The New England Patriots officially practiced for the first time on Wednesday ahead of Super Bowl LX against the Seattle Seahawks. Among those on the field at Stanford University was quarterback Drake Maye, who was limited all of last week with a shoulder injury and missed Friday's session with an illness.

results.title: Super Bowl LX injury report: Updates on Drake Maye's right shoulder, Sam Darnold's oblique, more - CBS Sports
results.snippet: Seahawks: Seattle had perfect attendance at practice, but did have several players limited: Quarterback Sam Darnold (oblique), offensive tackle Charles Cross (foot), safety Nick Emmanwori (ankle), offensive tackle Josh Jones (ankle, knee), linebacker Demarcus Lawrence (rest), fullback Robbie Ouzts (neck), receiver Jaxon Smith-Njigba (rest), and defensive end Leonard Williams (rest). Patriots: Linebacker Robert Spillane (ankle) did not practice on Wednesday due to an ankle injury. However, he did tell the Boston Herald earlier in the day that he's "100% confident" that he'll be able to play in Super Bowl LX. Meanwhile, linebacker Harold Landry (knee) and offensive tackle Thayer Munford Jr. were both limited with knee injuries. Maybe the most important development on the injury front for New England comes at quarterback as the team listed Drake Maye (right shoulder) as a full participant.

decision.reasoning:
<new_information>
The most material new information is the final confirmation of the injury status for both teams, particularly for Patriots QB Drake Maye. Multiple reports confirm he was a full participant in practice all week after previous concerns about a shoulder injury and an illness. He is "feeling great" and set to start. This removes any lingering uncertainty about the health of the Patriots' most important player.

For the Seahawks, the final injury report shows perfect practice attendance, but several key players were limited, including OT Charles Cross (foot) and S Nick Emmanwori (ankle
